Log Type Breakdown

 ‚óè Endpoint Security: 28 events ‚óè Authentication: 26 events ‚óè Email Gateway: 14 events
Severity Levels ‚óè INFO: 56 events ‚óè HIGH: 4 events ‚óè WARNING: 3 events ‚óè MEDIUM: 3 events ‚óè CRITICAL: 2 events

Most events are informational, but there are 9 high/critical severity incidents to pay attention to.

Event Timeline (Hourly)

Top 10 Source IPs Top 10 Destination IPs

Analysis & Impact
1.
Initial Attack Vector:
a.
The incident started with a successful phishing attack that allowed the attacker to steal the credentials of 'analyst1'.
b.
A malicious macro (T1204.002) was likely executed on WORKSTATION-01, enabling the attacker to establish an initial foothold.
2.
Persistence and Privilege Escalation:
a.
The Pass-the-Hash attack indicates an attempt to move laterally with elevated privileges.
b.
The Kerberos ticket request from an unusual host suggests an attempt to maintain persistence within the domain.
3.
Lateral Movement & Data Exfiltration:
a.
The attack involved multiple successful logins across the network, indicating an effort to establish a widespread foothold.
b.
The attempt to compromise the domain administrator account suggests an effort to gain full control over the infrastructure.


Recommendations for Incident Response
1.
Immediate Containment Measures:
a.
Isolate WORKSTATION-01 (192.168.1.10) and any other affected machines.
b.
Reset passwords and revoke access tokens for 'analyst1' and other compromised accounts.
c.
Conduct a forensic memory dump of the affected systems to identify any active malware.
2.
Threat Hunting & Eradication:
a.
Analyze EDR and SIEM logs for any further suspicious activity.
b.
Investigate scheduled tasks or registry modifications to detect persistence mechanisms (T1053).
c.
Revoke any suspicious Kerberos tickets and audit the Key Distribution Center (KDC) logs.
3.
Hardening & Long-term Security Measures:
a.
Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all privileged accounts.
b.
Improve email filtering to prevent spear-phishing attacks.
c.
Conduct security awareness training for employees to recognize phishing attempts.
d.
Enforce least privilege access policies to limit lateral movement potential.


Conclusion
APT 52 successfully compromised an employee‚Äôs credentials via a phishing attack, enabling them to execute malicious macros and perform credential abuse techniques like Pass-the-Hash and Kerberoasting. The attackers attempted to escalate privileges by targeting the domain administrator account, signaling a clear attempt at full domain compromise. Given the nature of the attack, it is imperative that Apex Financial takes immediate action to contain the breach, conduct a thorough forensic analysis, and enhance its security posture to prevent future incidents.

Email Notification

Subject:
Important Alert Regarding Email Phishing

Body:

Dear Team,

We want to inform you that a phishing email attack has been detected within our environment. The initial phishing email had the subject line ‚ÄúQ1 Performance Review‚Äù and included a malicious attachment titled ‚ÄúQ1_Performance_Review.pdf‚Äù. These malicious emails aim to trick recipients into clicking on harmful links or sharing sensitive information, which can compromise our systems and data.
Please familiarize yourself with our company‚Äôs email policies which will allow you to remain safe and vigilant. Always ensure that you are using multi-factor authentication when accessing any company portals or applications to add extra security for yourself and the company.

To help you stay vigilant, here are a few key indicators of phishing emails:
‚Ä¢
Unusual sender addresses or unexpected messages from known contacts.
‚Ä¢
Generic greetings such as "Dear User" instead of your name.
‚Ä¢
Urgent language pressuring you to take immediate action.
‚Ä¢
Suspicious links or attachments‚Äîhover over links to verify their destination before clicking.

If you receive an email that you suspect is a phishing attempt, please:

1.Do not click on any links or open attachments.
2. Report the email immediately by forwarding it to helpdesk@ourcompany.com
If you suspect you may have clicked on a link or shared any information, don't hesitate to contact the Helpdesk at helpdesk@ourcompany.com or (518) 555-5555 immediately for assistance.
Please be reminded to avoid sharing any confidential company information over email unless you‚Äôre sure who you‚Äôre sending it to.

Your awareness and prompt action are crucial in protecting our organization from cyber threats. Thank you for your cooperation and commitment to maintaining a secure environment.
